Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Respond promptly to emergency calls and reach the scene as quickly as possible
Situation2: The ambulance driver is on standby at the station, ready for any new dispatch to come in.
Story: I sat in the break room at the ambulance station, my phone buzzing with a message from my younger brother. He wanted to know if I could join him and his friends for dinner tonight, something we hadn’t done in months. He said it would mean a lot to him, that he missed hanging out like we used to. I knew how important it was to show up for him, to make him feel included and valued as my brother. But as I typed out a reply, the radio crackled with the dispatcher’s voice, reminding us to stay alert for any incoming emergency calls. My uniform felt heavier than usual, the responsibility pressing down on me. I wanted to be the sister who always showed up, but I was also the ambulance driver who couldn’t leave her post, not even for family. My heart tugged in two directions—toward the brother who needed me, and the city that might need me even more. I stared at my phone, torn, knowing that whatever I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
